history.content:
If you put significant time and effort into CS70, you should be able to get a B in the class. Now, since you haven't taken 54 and you will be a sophomore, the best track is probably to do EE 16A and B (and not take 54), so I would say take EE 16A.  You should try to finish the EE 16 series sooner rather than later, because the math is relevant for other courses.

16A is not too hard of a class (although some people do struggle with the circuits module, so you may want to preview it), but most of the time commitment will be the homework and  a 3 hour lab each week.

Besides these two, you can add another class for whatever requirements you need and it should be manageable.

children.subject: CS 61A, CS 70, EE 16A sounds manageable if you're willing to put in the work. For your fourth class, take something that won't be time consuming, though.

history.content:
I'm a CS freshman planning for the Fall 2017 semester, in which I plan to take CS70. I want to concentrate heavily on this class, since I've never taken a proof-based class before and will need a B to declare. I'm wondering what other CS requirements would be most doable alongside 70 in this regard (I haven't done 16A, 16B, or Math 54 yet)?

Thanks in advance.
history.subject: What to take alongside 70?
